q: What is the primary function of a 'Compute' service in cloud computing?
o: To provide processing power (cpu) and memory to run applications

q: Which of the following is an example of IaaS?
o: Virtual Machines (e.g., EC2, Azure VMs, Google Compute Engine)

q: Which of the following is an example of PaaS?
o: Heroku, Google App Engine, Azure App Service

q: Which of the following is an example of SaaS?

o: A software emulation of a physical computer

q: What is 'Object Storage' primarily used for?
o: Storing unstructured data like photos, videos, and backups

q: What is 'Block Storage' primarily used for?
o: Storing data for operating systems and databases (like a hard drive)

q: What is 'File Storage' in cloud terms?
o: Shared storage accessible by multiple machines via protocols like NFS or SMB
Cloud services offered over the public internet to anyone who wants to purchase them
Cloud computing resources used exclusively by a single business or organization
A computing environment that combines public cloud and private cloud/on-premises infrastructure
A mix of rain and snow
The ability to increase or decrease IT resources as needed to meet changing demand
The ability of a system to automatically adapt to workload changes by provisioning and de-provisioning resources
Systems designed to be durable and likely to operate continuously without failure for a long time
The ability of a system to continue operating properly in the event of the failure of some of its components
You only pay for the cloud resources you actually use, typically by the hour or second
You pay a flat monthly fee regardless of usage

q: What is a 'Region' in cloud infrastructure?
o: A geographic area containing one or more data centers
An isolated location within a region (e.g., a specific data center) designed to be independent of other AZs

q: What is the purpose of a 'Load Balancer'?
o: To distribute incoming network traffic across multiple servers to ensure reliability and performance
Automatically adjusting the number of compute resources based on defined rules or metrics
A point-in-time copy of a storage volume or filesystem
The time it takes for data to travel from source to destination
The amount of data moved successfully from one place to another in a given time period
Virtual Private Cloud, a logically isolated section of the cloud where you run your resources
A numerical label assigned to each device connected to a computer network
Domain Name System, like the phonebook of the internet (translates names to IPs)
Content Delivery Network, a system of distributed servers to deliver content closer to users
Processing data near the edge of the network, close to where it is generated, rather than a centralized cloud
A model where the cloud provider manages the server infrastructure, and you just run code (e.g., Functions)
A lightweight, standalone, executable package of software that includes everything needed to run an application
An open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications
An organized collection of structured information, or data, typically stored electronically
A database that stores data in tables with rows and columns, related by keys (e.g., SQL)
databases that store data in a format other than relational tables (e.g., Document, Key-Value)
A database with no SQL support ever
Data sets that are too large or complex to be dealt with by traditional data-processing application software
A system used for reporting and data analysis, storing large amounts of historical data
A framework of policies and technologies for ensuring that the right people have the appropriate access to technology resources
Verifying who a user is (e.g., password, biometrics)
Determining what permissions a user has (what they can access)
The process of encoding information so only authorized parties can access it
Protecting data that is stored on a disk or media
Protecting data while it is moving across a network (e.g., HTTPS)
A network security device that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic
Distributed Denial of Service, overwhelming a target with traffic
Adhering to laws, regulations, and guidelines (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA)
Moving data, applications, and other business elements to a cloud computing environment
The ability to rapidly develop, test, and launch software applications
Upfront costs for physical infrastructure (servers, buildings)
Ongoing costs for running a product, business, or system (like monthly cloud bills)
A framework defining security responsibilities between the cloud provider and the customer

q: In the Shared Responsibility Model, what is the Provider responsible for?
o: Security 'of' the cloud (hardware, physical datacenters, network infrastructure)

q: In the Shared Responsibility Model, what is the Customer responsible for?
o: Security 'in' the cloud (data, IAM, OS configuration, firewalls)
Architecture where a single instance of software serves multiple tenants (customers)
The provider's computing resources are pooled to serve multiple consumers
A consumer can provision computing capabilities automatically without human interaction
Capabilities are available over the network and accessed through standard mechanisms (phones, laptops)
Cloud systems automatically control and optimize resource use and meter it for billing
How the cloud infrastructure is deployed (Public, Private, Hybrid, Community)
Infrastructure shared by several organizations with common concerns (e.g., compliance, mission)
Dependency on a specific cloud provider's technology, making it hard to switch
Designing applications specifically to leverage cloud scalability and flexibility (microservices, containers)
Structuring an application as a collection of loosely coupled services
building an application as a single, unified unit
A set of practices combining software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops)
Managing and provisioning computer data centers through machine-readable definition files
Two regions within the same geography aimed at disaster recovery and data residency
The total cost of acquiring, operating, and maintaining an asset
Matching instance types and sizes to your workload performance and capacity requirements
Adding more power (CPU, RAM) to an existing machine
Adding more machines to your pool of resources
Virtual Private Network, creates a secure connection over a public network
Policies and procedures to recover technology infrastructure after a natural or human-induced disaster
The maximum acceptable amount of time to restore a system after a disaster
The maximum acceptable amount of data loss measured in time (e.g. 1 hour of data)
An application runs in a private cloud or data center and bursts into a public cloud when demand increases
Application Programming Interface, allows two applications to talk to each other
Representational State Transfer, a widely used architectural style for web APIs
JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data-interchange format
A contract between a service provider and a customer that defines the level of service expected
The time during which a system goes without a crash or restart
Periods when a system is unavailable
The process of setting up IT infrastructure
The process of removing access or freeing up resources
A generic NoSQL database where data is stored as a collection of key-value pairs
A NoSQL database designed for storing, retrieving and managing document-oriented information (e.g. JSON)
A database management system that stores data in columns rather than rows, good for analytics
A database that uses graph structures for semantic queries with nodes, edges, and properties (e.g., social networks)
A computer or system that provides resources, data, services, or programs to other computers
A computer hardware or software device that accesses a service made available by a server
A web-based interface to manage cloud resources
Command Line Interface, text-based interface to manage resources
Software Development Kit, tools for developers to create apps for a platform
Storage for data that is rarely accessed (archival)
Storage for data accessed less frequently than hot data but more than cold
Storage for data that requires frequent, fast access

q: What is the main benefit of 'Auto Scaling Groups'?
o: Ensures optimal performance and cost by adding/removing instances based on demand
Keeping a fixed number of servers
A billing discount applied to the use of On-Demand Instances in exchange for a commitment (1 or 3 years)
Purchasing unused compute capacity at a steep discount, with the risk of interruption
Limited by the maximum capacity of a single machine (CPU/RAM limits)
A logical subdivision of an IP network
A subnet that has a direct route to the internet gateway
A subnet accessible by everyone without passwords
A subnet that does not have a direct route to the internet gateway
Allowing instances in a private subnet to connect to the internet (e.g. for updates) but preventing the internet from initiating connections
A direct network connection between two VPCs (possibly in different accounts) that allows them to communicate as if they were in the same network
A network transit hub that connects VPCs and on-premises networks
Tiering data based on access frequency (Hot, Cool, Archive) to optimize cost

q: What is 'Lifecycle Policy' in object storage?
o: Rules to automatically move data to cheaper storage classes or delete it after a set time
Keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket (preserves, creates new versions on overwrite)
Automatically copying data from a bucket in one region to a bucket in another region
A copy of the primary database used to serve read-only traffic, offloading the primary
Splitting a large database into smaller, faster, more easily managed parts called data shards
Basically Available, Soft state, Eventual consistency
Ideally, all reads will return the last written value, but there is no guarantee of how long this might take
Guarantees that a read returns the most recent write
Collecting and analyzing metrics (CPU, RAM, Network) to understand system health
Records of events that occur within an application or system
Notifying operators when metrics cross a threshold (e.g. CPU > 90%)
A security system that requires more than one method of authentication (password + phone code)
Restricting system access to authorized users based on their roles within an organization
Giving a user only those privileges which are essential to perform their work
Strategy/tools ensuring that sensitive data is not lost, misused, or accessed by unauthorized users
General Data Protection Regulation (EU privacy law)
Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (US health data privacy)
A auditing procedure that ensures your service providers securely manage your data
The encryption of data at its destination by the application or service that receives it
Encrypting data on the client side before uploading it to the cloud
Encryption where the same key is used to encrypt and decrypt the message
Encryption using a pair of keys: a public key to encrypt and a private key to decrypt
A managed service that makes it easy for you to create and control the cryptographic keys used to encrypt your data
A physical server with EC2 instance capacity fully dedicated to your use (compliance)
A configuration that determines how instances are placed on underlying hardware (Cluster, Spread, Partition)
Places instances on distinct hardware to reduce correlated failures
Packs instances close together inside an Availability Zone (low latency)
A static IPv4 address designed for dynamic cloud computing (persists after stop/start)
A horizontally scaled, redundant, and highly available VPC component that allows communication between your VPC and the internet
A server tasked with providing access to a private network from an external network (usually for SSH)
Helps protect your web applications or APIs against common web exploits (SQL injection, XSS)
A technique that reduces downtime and risk by running two identical production environments called Blue and Green
Rolling out changes to a small subset of users before making it available to everyone
Updating instances one by one or in batches to avoid downtime
Updating the application on the existing instances (downtime possible)
Never modifying servers after they're deployed; replacing them with new ones instead
Identifying when the actual infrastructure configuration differs from the defined IaC template
Components are independent; a change in one doesn't break others (often uses queues)
Virtual clusters backed by the same physical cluster (logical isolation)
The smallest deployable unit of computing that you can create and manage in Kubernetes
An abstraction which defines a logical set of Pods and a policy by which to access them
Ensures that a specified number of pod replicas are running at any given time
An API object that manages external access to the services in a cluster, typically HTTP
An API object used to store non-confidential data in key-value pairs
An object that contains a small amount of sensitive data such as a password, a token, or a key
A form of asynchronous service-to-service communication used in serverless and microservices architectures
Ensuring components can scale and fail independently
A queue where messages that cannot be processed successfully are moved for analysis
First-In-First-Out, ensures message order is preserved
High throughput, best-effort ordering, at-least-once delivery
A named resource to which messages are sent by publishers
A named resource representing the stream of messages from a single, specific topic, to be delivered to the subscribing application
A software architecture paradigm promoting the production, detection, consumption of, and reaction to events
Periodically checking a resource status to see if it has changed
The server sends data to the client when it becomes available
Often optimizing for max throughput increases latency (batching), and optimizing for low latency reduces throughput
A pre-configured template for a virtual machine instance (OS + Apps + Config)
The process of installing software and dependencies on a server when it launches
A script passed to the cloud instance to run upon first boot
A service accessible from within a VM (often 169.254.169.254) to get info about itself
Network Access Control List, an optional layer of security for your VPC that acts as a firewall for controlling traffic in/out of subnets
Security Groups are stateful (return traffic auto-allowed); NACLs are stateless (return traffic must be explicitly allowed)
It remembers the state of the connection (if request goes out, reply is deemed safe)
It checks every packet individually against rules, regardless of previous packets
Classless Inter-Domain Routing, a method for allocating IP addresses and IP routing (e.g. 10.0.0.0/16)
The concept that digital data is subject to the laws or regulations of the country in which it is located
Input/Output Operations Per Second, a performance metric for storage
Buying a guaranteed level of IOPS performance for a volume
Low cost HDD designed for frequently accessed, throughput-intensive workloads (Big Data, Logs)
Lowest cost HDD design for less frequently accessed workloads
Balances price and performance for a wide variety of transactional workloads
A database that automatically starts up, shuts down, and scales capacity based on application's needs
Replicates your data automatically across your choice of regions
Tags used to organize your resource costs on your cost allocation report
Setting custom budgets that alert you when your costs or usage exceed (or generally differ from) your budgeted amount

q: What is 'Support Plan' (Basic, Developer, Business, Enterprise)?
o: Different tiers of support offering varying response times and access to experts
A designated technical point of contact who provides advocacy and guidance (Enterprise support)
An authoritative report or guide that informs readers concisely about a complex issue
A document or set of documents that provides recommended structures and integrations of IT products and services
A digital catalog with thousands of software listings from independent software vendors
Model that lets you use your existing software licenses (Windows, SQL) on the cloud
Efforts to reduce the carbon footprint of cloud operations (renewable energy, efficiency)
Temporary storage that is deleted when an instance is stopped or terminated
Encrypting plaintext data with a data key, and then encrypting the data key with a master key
Putting a letter in an envelope
A dedicated physical network connection from your premises to the cloud provider (bypassing public internet)
Configuring DNS resolution across on-premises and cloud environments (forwarders/resolvers)
A compilation of routine procedures and operations that the system administrator or operator carries out
Structured planning and support for large-scale events (launches, marketing)
A service to centrally manage and govern your environment as you grow and scale your workloads (multiple accounts)
A policy that manages permissions in your organization, setting maximum available permissions for accounts
A feature to see a combined view of charges for all accounts in the organization
A service that enables you to share resources (like subnets) with any account in your organization
A tool that enables you to visualize, understand, and manage your cloud costs and usage over time
A tool that provides real-time guidance to help you provision resources following best practices (Cost, Security, Performance)
The maximum number of resources that you can create in an account (soft vs hard limits)
Cloud providers often require prior approval or have specific rules for penetration testing your own resources
The identity that has complete access to all services and resources in the account (should be protected)
An IaC service that gives you an easy way to model a collection of related cloud and third-party resources
Creating stacks as part of other stacks to create a hierarchy of resources
Difference between the expected stack configuration and the actual resource configuration
An easy-to-use service for deploying and scaling web applications and services (PaaS)
A service that automates code deployments to any instance, including EC2 and on-premises
A fully managed continuous delivery service that helps you automate your release pipelines
A fully managed build service that compiles source code, runs tests, and produces software packages
A fully managed source control service that hosts secure Git-based repositories
A service to analyze and debug distributed applications, such as those built using a microservices architecture
A visual representation of the application's components and how they talk to each other (latency/errors)
Provides authentication, authorization, and user management for your web and mobile apps
A user directory in Cognito (Sign-up, Sign-in)
Enables you to grant your users access to other cloud services
A central service to manage access to multiple accounts and distinct applications
Managed Microsoft Active Directory in the cloud
An automated security assessment service that helps improve the security and compliance of applications
A threat detection service that continuously monitors for malicious activity and unauthorized behavior
Fully managed data security and data privacy service that uses machine learning to protect sensitive data
Managed Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) protection service
Central resource for compliance-related information (security reports, certifications)
An interactive query service that makes it easy to analyze data in S3 using standard SQL
A fully managed extract, transform, and load (ETL) service that makes it easy to prepare data for analytics
Platform for streaming data on AWS (Video, Data Streams, Firehose)
A fast, cloud-powered business intelligence service (visualizations/dashboards)
Fully managed service to build, train, and deploy machine learning models
Service that turns text into lifelike speech
Service that makes it easy to add image and video analysis to your applications
Neural machine translation service that delivers fast, high-quality, and affordable language translation
Automatic speech recognition (ASR) service that makes it easy to add speech-to-text capability
A fully managed messaging service for both application-to-application (A2A) and application-to-person (A2P) communication
Cost-effective, flexible, and scalable email service that enables developers to send mail from within any application
Serverless function orchestrator that makes it easy to sequence AWS Lambda functions and multiple services
A serverless event bus that makes it easy to connect applications together using data from your own apps, SaaS, and AWS services
An easy-to-use cloud platform (VPS) that offers everything needed to build an application or website
A fully managed service that extends AWS infrastructure, services, APIs, and tools to customer premises (Hybrid)
An extension of a Region giving you the ability to place resources closer to end users (single city)
Bringing AWS services to the edge of the 5G network (ultra-low latency)
A petabyte-scale data transport solution that uses devices to transfer large amounts of data into and out of the cloud
An exabyte-scale data transfer service used to move extremely large amounts of data to AWS (Truck)
A hybrid cloud storage service that gives you on-premises access to virtually unlimited cloud storage
Fully managed third-party file systems (Windows File Server, Lustre)
A simple, serverless, set-and-forget, elastic file system (NFS)
MySQL and PostgreSQL-compatible relational database built for the cloud (Performance and Availability)
A fast, simple, cost-effective data warehousing service
A fast, reliable, fully managed graph database service
A fast, scalable, highly available, and fully managed document database service that supports MongoDB workloads
Fully managed Redis and Memcached (in-memory caching)
A fast, scalable, and serverless time series database service
A fully managed ledger database that provides a transparent, immutable, and cryptographically verifiable transaction log
A fully managed service that makes it easy to create and manage scalable blockchain networks
A fully managed, highly available, in-memory cache for DynamoDB
A networking service that improves the performance of your users' traffic by up to 60% using the AWS global network
Provides private connectivity between VPCs, services, and your on-premises networks (without internet)
Virtual devices that enable you to privately connect your VPC to supported AWS services
Interface uses PrivateLink (ENI) generally costly; Gateway uses route table (S3/DynamoDB) generally free
The easiest way to set up and govern a secure, multi-account environment
A secure, multi-account, scalable AWS environment based on best practices
Recommends optimal AWS Compute resources for your workloads to reduce costs and improve performance
A set of best practices for designing and operating reliable, secure, efficient, and cost-effective systems in the cloud

q: What are the Pillars of Well-Architected Framework?
o: Operational Excellence, Security, Reliability, Performance Efficiency, Cost Optimization, Sustainability
A flexible pricing model that offers low prices on usage (EC2, Lambda, Fargate) in exchange for a commitment (better than RIs)
Offers distinct types of free services allowing you to try AWS (Always Free, 12 Months Free, Trials)
Assigning metadata to resources (Key-Value pairs) for organization, cost tracking, and security
A collection of resources that share one or more tags or parts of a region
Visibility and control of your infrastructure (Run Command, Patch Manager, Session Manager)
Managed, secure, auditable instances management without opening inbound ports (No SSH keys needed)
Provides secure, hierarchical storage for configuration data management and secrets management
A configuration management service that provides managed instances of Chef and Puppet
Converting media files from their source format into versions that will play back on devices
Reliably load streaming data into data lakes, data stores, and analytics services
Transform and analyze streaming data in real time with Apache Flink
Automated reference deployments built by AWS solutions architects and partners
Technical experts who help you design and build applications
A global team of experts that can help you realize your desired business outcomes when using the cloud
Global community of partners (Consulting/Technology) that leverages programs, expertise, and resources
Contains the most frequent questions and requests from customers
Service for connecting customers with AWS-certified third-party experts for on-demand project work
Moving applications to the cloud without making changes
Making a few cloud optimizations to achieve some tangible benefit without changing the core architecture
Reimagining how an application is architected and developed via cloud-native features
Moving to a different product, likely a SaaS platform (e.g. CRM to Salesforce)
Turning off applications that are no longer needed
Organizes guidance into six perspectives (Business, People, Governance, Platform, Security, Operations)
Limiting the scope of impact of a failure
Gradually migrating a legacy system by replacing specific pieces of functionality with new applications and services
A pattern that separates read and update operations for a data store
Storing the state of changes as a sequence of events
Using different data storage technologies to handle different data storage needs within a given application
Making multiple identical requests has the same effect as making a single request
Prevents an application from repeatedly trying to execute an operation that's likely to fail
Isolating elements of an application into pools so that if one fails, the others will continue to function
Deploying components of an application into a separate process or container to provide isolation and encapsulation (e.g. logging agent)
Creating helper services that send network requests on behalf of a consumer service or application (Proxy)
Broadcasting a message to multiple recipients and re-aggregating the responses back into a single message

q: What is 'Transitive Routing' in AWS VPC?
o: Connecting one VPC to another via a middle VPC (Not supported natively by VPC Peering, requires Transit Gateway)
A cloud-based hardware security module that enables you to easily generate and use your own encryption keys
A URL that grants temporary access to a specific S3 object
Uploading a single object as a set of parts (improves throughput and recovery for large files)
Enables fast, easy, and secure transfers of files over long distances between your client and an S3 bucket (using Edge locations)

q: What is 'Origin Access Identity' (OAI) or OAC?
o: A special CloudFront user identity used to restrict access to S3 content so that users can only access it through CloudFront
Running Lambda functions at CloudFront Edge locations to customize content delivery
Lightweight functions written in JavaScript for high-scale, latency-sensitive CDN customizations (lighter than Lambda@Edge)
Pre-configured sets of rules managed by AWS or AWS Marketplace Sellers to address common threats
A service that enables you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources
Rules used by AWS Config to check whether your resources are compliant with desired configurations
Automatic or manual actions to fix non-compliant resources
Copying network traffic from an elastic network interface of Amazon EC2 instances to a target for analysis
Capturing information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces in your VPC
Instance Store is ephemeral (data lost on stop); EBS is persistent (data saved on stop)
Incremental (only blocks that have changed since your last snapshot are saved)
An instance that provides a dedicated network stack for your EBS I/O
Keeps functions initialized and ready to respond in double-digit milliseconds (removes cold start)
A pointer to a specific function version (can be used for Blue/Green deployment)
A ZIP archive that contains libraries, a custom runtime, or other dependencies (share code across functions)
A serverless compute engine for containers (works with ECS and EKS)
Simplifies the building, testing, and deployment of Virtual Machine and container images
A fully managed service that makes it easy for developers to quickly deploy containerized web applications and APIs
A tool for developers to build, release, and operate production-ready containerized applications on AWS App Runner or ECS
Fully managed service for platform engineers to automate and manage infrastructure provisioning for serverless and container-based apps
Attaching just the right amount of GPU-powered inference acceleration to any EC2 or SageMaker instance
AWS custom chip designed to provide high performance and low cost machine learning inference
AWS custom processor built using 64-bit Arm Neoverse cores (Cost/Performance benefit)
The underlying platform for the next generation of EC2 instances (Hypervisor offload to hardware)
A service that logs, continuously monitors, and retains account activity related to actions across your AWS infrastructure
CloudTrail logs 'Who did what' (API calls); CloudWatch monitors 'What is happening' (Metrics, Logs, Events)
DAX is specifically for DynamoDB (write-through); ElastiCache is generic (Memcached/Redis)
Pay per query (based on amount of data scanned)
Retrieving only a subset of data from an object by using simple SQL expressions (reduces data transfer)
Expedited (1-5 min), Standard (3-5 hours), Bulk (5-12 hours)
Prevents an object from being deleted or overwritten for a fixed amount of time or indefinitely (WORM)
Automatically moves data between frequent and infrequent access tiers when access patterns change
A centralized caching layer that helps reduce load on your origin
Used to deploy, scale, and manage virtual appliances (firewalls, IDS/IPS)
Best for high performance / throughput, handles volatile traffic patterns (Layer 4)
Best for HTTP/HTTPS traffic, advanced routing (Layer 7)
Routing requests from the same client to the same target
Distributing traffic evenly across all registered targets in all enabled Availability Zones
Giving in-flight requests time to complete before deregistering a target
Using a virtual private gateway to connect multiple Site-to-Site VPN connections (hub-and-spoke)
Architecture for secure communication between multiple remote sites
Allows you to connect your Direct Connect connection to one or more VPCs in your account that are located in different regions
Simple, Weighted, Latency, Failover, Geolocation, Geoproximity, Multivalue Answer
Routing traffic to multiple resources in proportions that you specify (e.g., 80/20)
Routing traffic to the region that provides the best latency (lowest response time)
Routing traffic to a backup resource when the primary resource is unhealthy (Active-Passive)
Routing traffic based on the geographic location of your users
Routing traffic based on geographic location of your users AND your resources (uses bias)
Returning multiple values (IPs) for a DNS query (simple load balancing)
CloudTrail Events, VPC Flow Logs, DNS Logs
A comprehensive view of your high-priority security alerts and compliance status across AWS accounts
Analysing, investigating, and identifying the root cause of potential security issues or suspicious activities
Online data transfer service that simplifies, automates, and accelerates moving data between on-premises storage systems and AWS storage services
Tool to convert your existing database schema from one database engine to another
Helps you migrate databases to AWS quickly and securely (source remains operational)
The primary service for lift-and-shift migrations to AWS
A single place to track the progress of application migrations across AWS and partner solutions
Helps you continuously audit your AWS usage to simplify how you assess risk and compliance
Flexible pricing model that provides savings up to 66% on compute usage (EC2, Fargate, Lambda) regardless of region/family
Provides savings up to 72% but requires commitment to a specific instance family in a specific region
Reserved spot instances for a specific duration (1-6 hours)
A collection of Spot Instances, and optionally On-Demand Instances
Reserving compute capacity for your EC2 instances in a specific Availability Zone for any duration
Session-oriented method for retrieving instance metadata (more secure than v1)
A network interface for Amazon EC2 instances that enables customers to run HPC applications requiring high levels of inter-node communications
Provides high-performance networking capabilities on EC2 instances
Spreads your instances across logical partitions such that groups of instances in one partition do not share standard hardware with other partitions
Regions, Availability Zones, Edge Locations, Local Zones, Wavelength Zones
Regional services exist in a specific region (EC2); Global services exist across all regions (IAM, Route53, CloudFront)
Amazon Resource Name, uniquely identifies AWS resources
A person or application that can make a request for an action or operation on an AWS resource
An object in AWS that, when associated with an identity or resource, defines their permissions

q: What is 'Access Key ID' & 'Secret Access Key'?
o: Long-term credentials for an IAM user or the AWS account root user
Short-term credentials created by AWS STS (Security Token Service)
An API call to obtain a set of temporary security credentials that you use to access AWS resources
A mechanism to let a principal use a KMS key if certain conditions are met
A logical representation of a master key in AWS KMS
Encryption keys that you use to encrypt data (generated by CMK)
Provides higher bandwidth, higher packet per second (PPS) performance, and consistently lower inter-instance latencies (using SR-IOV)
A method of device virtualization that provides higher I/O performance and lower CPU utilization (bypasses hypervisor)
Low-latency, high-bandwidth connections between instances in a Placement Group
Ethernet frames with more than 1500 bytes of payload (up to 9000 bytes) - increases throughput, reduces CPU load
The period of time during which flow logs capture and aggregate traffic (default 10 min, max 1 min)
No transitive peering, no overlapping CIDRs, 125 active peering connections per VPC (soft limit)
Allows DNS queries between your VPC and your network (on-premises) via forwarding rules
Configuring DNS so that you use the same domain name for internal and external access to your website (internal IP vs public IP)
Configuration in a VPC to control aspects of TCP/IP networking (domain name, DNS servers, NTP servers)
You can add secondary IPv4 CIDR blocks to your VPC (cannot modify primary block size)
Attaching a single io1/io2 EBS volume to multiple instances in the same AZ (Cluster-aware file system needed)
Striping data across multiple volumes for higher performance (no redundancy)
Mirroring data across volumes for redundancy (fault tolerance)
Dumps RAM to EBS volume upon stopping, allowing faster resume (application state preserved)
Runs with root privileges, only on the first boot cycle (unless modified to run on every boot)

q: What is 'Allowed IP Spoofing' in VPC?
o: Not allowed. AWS infrastructure drops traffic with a source IP or MAC address that isn't authorized
Generally not available for network interfaces in a VPC (makes sniffing hard)
File Gateway (S3), Volume Gateway (iSCSI Block), Tape Gateway (VTL)
All data is stored locally on-premises, and backed up effectively to AWS as EBS snapshots
Primary data is in S3, frequently accessed data is cached locally on-premises
Strong read-after-write consistency for all objects (PUTs and DELETEs included)
Retrieving only a specific range of bytes from an object (parallelize downloads)
The requester paying for data transfer and requests instead of the bucket owner
S3 can serve files via the BitTorrent protocol (saves bandwidth for popular files)
Requiring MFA code to permanently delete an object version or change versioning state (Root user only)
1 RCU = 1 strongly consistent read/sec (4KB); 1 WCU = 1 write/sec (1KB)
Dynamically adjusts provisioned throughput capacity on your behalf in response to actual traffic
LSI (Local Secondary Index) created at table creation, same partition key; GSI (Global Secondary Index) creates anytime, different partition key
Automatically deletes items that fail to meet a timestamp condition (expiration)
A container for engine configuration values (e.g. max_connections) applied to one or more instances
Enabling features (e.g. Transparent Data Encryption, Memcached) that are not default
Cluster Endpoint (Writer), Reader Endpoint (Load Balances Readers), Custom Endpoint, Instance Endpoint
Creating a new cluster that shares storage with original (Copy-on-Write) - fast and cheap
Rewinding the DB cluster to a specific time, without restoring from backup (very fast)

q: What is 'CloudFront Signed URL' vs 'Signed Cookie'?
o: URL for individual file access; Cookie for access to multiple files/folders
Removing files from CloudFront edge caches before they expire
Allowing multiple SSL certificates for different domains on the same IP address/Listener
Legacy load balancer (Layer 4/7), distinct from ALB/NLB (generation 1)
Identifies the originating IP address of a client connecting to a web server through an HTTP proxy or load balancer
Used to pass connection information (source IP) to the backend for TCP listeners (NLB/CLB)

q: What is 'Direct Connect' LAG (Link Aggregation Group)?
o: Aggregating multiple Direct Connect connections into a single managed connection (higher bandwidth)
The routing protocol used to exchange routing and reachability information (used in Direct Connect/VPN)
A unique number assigned to an AS (network) for use in BGP routing
Performing calculations across multiple metrics for real-time analysis (e.g. ErrorRate = Errors / Requests)
Applying machine learning algorithms to continuous metric data to identify anomalous behavior
Configurable scripts that monitor your endpoints and APIs from the outside-in (simulating user traffic)
A trail that logs events for all AWS accounts in an organization (created in management account)
KMS generates new cryptographic material for the CMK every year (older data can still be decrypted)
Keys that have the same key material and ID in different regions (for easier DR/Global applications)
Secrets Manager has automatic rotation, cross-account access, and higher cost; Parameter Store is free/cheap, manual rotation
Launch Template is the newer, versioned, feature-rich replacement for Launch Configuration (supports T2/T3 unlimited, Spot fleets)
Automatically recovering an instance if the system status check fails (moves to new hardware)
Maximum 7 instances per Availability Zone per group
Host gives control over socket/core placement (licensing); Instance just guarantees hardware separation
Moving your publicly routable IPv4 addresses to AWS
Creates a virtual perimeter for a real-world geographic area (triggers events)
A JSON document that is used to store and retrieve current state information for a device
Software that extends cloud capabilities to local devices (run Lambda/Docker locally)
An open source, real-time operating system for microcontrollers
Service to simulate, test, and deploy robotics applications
Fully managed service that lets you control satellite communications
Service to create and run virtual reality (VR), augmented reality (AR), and 3D applications
1/18th scale race car which gives you an interesting way to get started with reinforcement learning (RL)
Deep learning enabled video camera for developers
Negotiated custom pricing and terms for a product in AWS Marketplace
Service creating applications that run on AWS and billing customers for them (Legacy, mostly replaced by Marketplace)
Crowdsourcing marketplace that makes it easier for individuals and businesses to outsource their processes and jobs
Infrastructure deployments that embed AWS compute and storage services within telecommunications providers' data centers (5G edge)

q: What is 'Local Zone' parent region relationship?
o: Local Zone is an extension of a parent Region; control plane is in the parent Region
caching content for CloudFront and DNS resolution for Route 53
Larger cache between Origin and Edge Location (improves cache hit ratio)
The time it takes to create a new execution environment, download code, and start the runtime
You pay for the amount of concurrency you configure and for the duration you configure it
Visual tool that makes it easier to design and build serverless applications
Securely analyze and collaborate on datasets without revealing underlying data
Build dynamic, large-scale spatial simulations on AWS
End-to-end encrypted messaging and collaboration service
Cloud-based application that unifies data and provides ML-powered actionable insights for supply chain
Provide secure access to corporate applications without a VPN
Unified software development service to quickly build and deliver applications on AWS
Unlock data across organizational boundaries with built-in governance
Easiest way to build and scale generative AI applications with foundation models (FMs)
Generative AI-powered assistant designed for work
An Amazon Bedrock Playground to build AI apps
Isolated compute environments to protect highly sensitive data
Linux-based operating system meant for hosting containers
Open source virtualization technology that is purpose-built for creating and managing secure, multi-tenant container and function-based services
Capability that enables Aurora to understand queries from applications written for SQL Server (T-SQL)

q: What is 'S3 Select' vs 'S3 Glacier Select'?
o: Both allow SQL filtering; Glacier Select works on archived data (slower)
Service that makes it easy to set up a secure data lake in days
Feature that lets you run queries against exabytes of unstructured data in Amazon S3 without loading it
Automatically adds transient capacity to handle high concurrency
Run applications without configuring, optimizing, securing, or operating clusters

q: What is 'MSK' (Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka)?
o: Fully managed service to build and run applications that use Apache Kafka to process streaming data

q: What is 'MWAA' (Managed Workflows for Apache Airflow)?
o: Highly available, secure, and fully managed workflow orchestration service for Apache Airflow
